A set is a collection of distinct objects considered as an entity.
Let $G$ be a group and $S \subset G$ a subset. The normalizer of $S$ in $G$ is given by $N_{S}=\{x \in G ; x S=S x\}$.
Does the concept of a/an Set need to be defined for a definition of a/an Normalizer to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The definition of a Normalizer involves the concept of a subset $S$ which is part of a group $G$. A subset is inherently a type of set, specifically a set that contains elements all of which are also elements of a larger set, in this case, the group $G$. Therefore, understanding what a set is becomes crucial to comprehending what a subset is. Since the normalizer $N_{S}$ is defined using the subset $S$, the concept of a set must first be understood to grasp the definition of a normalizer. Thus, the concept of a set is necessary for the definition of a normalizer to make sense.
